Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit where it wants to - "waiting my turn" -, while the Dutch continue with "you don't belong here." How very 17th century!

Although we are in London and not Amsterdam, that maritime privileged first-world 'conflict' seems very evident.

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. Unfortunately the story is incredibly clichéd and excuses plenty of war atrocities in order to give New Zealand‘s most famous figurehead a place in history.

The Bone Snatcher is about a group miners who go on a search for a missing crew of miners in the Namib Desert. When the find them, they do not realize that what was going on with them is going to happen to them and may be worse than what happened to those poor guys.
I stumbled across The Bone Snatcher when I saw someone reading it in hardcover at the library while my daughter and I were picking out books.  It looked good, so

I saw it tonight and fell asleep in the movie.

That is something that I have not done since - I have never fallen asleep at a real movie, like going to the theater and watching it. With movies you can watch in your house,I fall asleep all the time.

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly an attempt to catch the success of The Ninja has just been released on DVD, and it’s one of those films that’s so bad that it can’t help but be hilarious at times.
